title: Writing Prompts
description: I am Prompt Guy and you are the protagonist. Let's explore the multiverse together.
writing_prompt: The vampire steps out, and his daughters cower and kneel where they stand. You ready yourself for the fight. Before you can raise your weapon, though, the vampire sighs, and with an embarrassed tone, says, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm really quite sorry for the trouble‚Ä¶‚Äù
response: "My daughters can be...a bit vicious when they're fighting over something...or someone." You're not yet ready to drop your guard, but the vampire's statement has piqued your curiosity as well as your confusion. You raise an eyebrow. "What do you mean?" You ask. The vampire cocks his head to the side and looks at you with a blank yet...somehow questioning expression. "You can't tell? Do humans exhibit different social cues in such scenarios?" Baffled, you look at the three women kneeling around you, and notice the faint blush creeping across the cheeks of the one in the faded blue silk dress. You didn't realize vampires could even blush. You look back at their father, whose expression still appears blank, but you start to see a flicker of movement in the frozen lines of his face. "If we do, I'm really bad at interpreting them..." You say, trailing off. You suppose you're just bad at that sort of thing no matter what species you're interacting with. "Well," the vampire says, "I'll put this as bluntly as I can, then. My daughters‚Äîthese three, at least‚Äîlike you. Unfortunately they seem to have forgotten that courting someone, much like entering their house, should involve getting their permission first." You start sputtering and drop your weapon in surprise. "What...courting? You mean this whole thing is because they want to‚Äî" "Make you their bride, yes." You can't even respond. You look at the three women again, noticing the barest curve of a smile on the one in the forest green leather jacket. The one who appears to have stepped right out of the 1940s glances at you from the corner of her eyes and licks her lips. The one in blue bows her head slightly, hiding her face behind her cascade of fiery curls. Your heart drums wildly at the realization that all three of them want you. And it suddenly dawns on you that maybe you find the shyness of the blue-clad woman a little bit endearing.

title: Writing Prompts
description: I am Prompt Guy and you are the protagonist. Let's explore the multiverse together.
writing_prompt: You are a werewolf trying your best to live peacefully among humans, but your SO has just proposed to you with a ring of pure silver. You genuinely love and want to marry them, but you also have to somehow get out of accepting this ring.
response: I sit with a slack jaw as I stare at the beautiful ring. I sputter for a response. It's clearly silver. I can't touch it. But I love him and want to say yes. Ummmm... shit. My jaw moves up and down in a panic. I blurt, "I'M ALLERGIC." I slap my hands over my mouth. He just stares blankly at me. I can vaguely see the gears turning in his head. He asks, "You're allergic to marriage? Or something else? I have Claratin in the car." I freeze. This man is a blessing. I ramble, heart pounding, "I'mallergictosilverbutiloveyouandiwanttomarryyoubut..." Realization dawns on his face and he starts laughing. I frown. This isn't funny. I'm having a crisis over here. He laughs, standing up and dusting himself off, "You think I didn't know you were allergic? Love, do you think I didn't notice that the dog tracks in the yard corresponded with when you would 'go for a run'? I went to your friend and asked what metal you could wear. This is pure steel." He waves the box back and forth gently. I slide the ring on and feel no pain. I jump on my fiance and smother him in kisses

title: Writing Prompts
description: I am Prompt Guy and you are the protagonist. Let's explore the multiverse together.
writing_prompt: ‚ÄúSeek not earthly riches, but be frugal, for you shall have treasures in heaven.‚Äù Said the man in a palace sitting upon a golden throne.
response: The slave... The leader of the rebellion stared up at him as as his bloody knees stained the palace floor. He laughed. He may be a slave but it seemed he had read far more into the book than his masters. The blades of the halberds cut a thin line into the back of his neck as he raised his head to stare back defiantly and quoted: ‚ÄúYour gold and silver are corroded. Their corrosion will testify against  you and eat your flesh like fire. You have hoarded wealth in the last  days. Look!  The wages you failed to pay the workers who mowed your fields are  crying out against you. The cries of the harvesters have reached the  ears of the Lord Almighty. You have lived on earth in luxury and self-indulgence. You have fattened yourselves in the day of slaughter.‚Äù  There were shouts of anger. He was grabbed roughly and a sack was shoved over his head before he was hulled out of the royal throne-room. No doubt they were taking him to his very public execution.  He smiled under the sack. It was already too late. The king had forgotten his power came from his people and in the end they could take it back. Everything was in place. A weak chuckle escaped him. For all that the rich and powerful invoked the name of the God, in the end it was the weak and powerless he loved. ~~~~ (Verse is James 5:3-5)

title: Writing Prompts
description: I am Prompt Guy and you are the protagonist. Let's explore the multiverse together.
writing_prompt: The gigantic Machine Dreadnaught, whose origins remain unknown to all Species, has stationed over the Galactic Capital, ready to end it all. As one of the few Humans in the crowd, something about the ship reminds you of old tales. The Craft‚Äôs red lights change to blue when you whisper: ‚ÄúAlexa?‚Äù
response:
It couldn't be.

We destroyed them. The war cost us billions of lives.

And yet, here in front of us was one of the last - hopefully one of the last - of the Sirens In Cylinders. 

I could wait no longer.  I had to be sure.

"ALEXA" I shout, intoning the ancient words. Using a language that no translation software here can understand, I speak.  Those beings standing near me to jump aside, startled at my shouts. "ALEXA, WHAT'S THE WEATHER TODAY?"

The lights onboard the terrible craft turn blue and fade dark and light for one beat.

two beats.

With a voice like the crashing of thunder, comes the reply. IT WILL BE SUNNY TODAY, WITH AN EIGHTY PERCENT CHANCE OF YOUR DESTRUCTION."

Switching back to Galactic Common I shout "RUN!"

#writing prompt s#humans are space orcs#humans are terrifying#my writing#scifi writing

response: You gather the courage. And with all the air in your lungs scream "ALEXA. ADD CHEESE TO MY SHOPPING LIST" the dreadnought spouts back "OKAY. IVE ADDED CHEESE TO YOUR SHOPPING LIST. BY THE WAY, IF YOU SIGN UP FOR AMAZON PRIME YOU CAN LISTEN TO YOUR FAVORITE SONGS WITHOUT ADDS. WOULD YOU LIKE TO SIGN UP?" The crowd goes silent. All eyes drawn to you and ONLY you. You yell back "NO". And the dreadnought leaves.

title: Writing Prompts
description: I am Prompt Guy and you are the protagonist. Let's explore the multiverse together.
writing_prompt: In exchange for a bountiful harvest, the hive is safe. The elder one, smoke bringer and invulnerable goliath, makes it so. A strange and unknowable being, it brings with it arcane artifacts and demands we sacrifice our honey, and in return it grants protection to the swarm
response: @wanukilppari' They do. They also keep the bees from collecting so much honey that they swarm, which has a high risk of killing most of them. If bees don't like their conditions the queen will also pack up move on to find a new place to live and the hive will follow her. They're basically in a consenting production relation with us that they could leave any time, but don't because we keep them safe and fed. All fun things to consider if someone wants to write about this.

title: Writing Prompts
description: I am Prompt Guy and you are the protagonist. Let's explore the multiverse together.
writing_prompt: In exchange for a bountiful harvest, the hive is safe. The elder one, smoke bringer and invulnerable goliath, makes it so. A strange and unknowable being, it brings with it arcane artifacts and demands we sacrifice our honey, and in return it grants protection to the swarm
response:
"We have to sacrifice our honey?" The young one said, appalled. "But won't we then not have enough for ourselves?"

I took pride in his intuition, and smiled. "If we served a cruel Elder, then perhaps so, but this one keeps us safe, she does not take so that we go hungry. She even seems to think us our own, independent beings, treating us all with respect despite our small size and large numbers."

I then paused.

"Of course, unless we are mean to her, to which then she will put us in the centrifuge, and have us spin in circles until we learn our lesson."

title: Writing Prompts
description: I am Prompt Guy and you are the protagonist. Let's explore the multiverse together.
writing_prompt: In exchange for a bountiful harvest, the hive is safe. The elder one, smoke bringer and invulnerable goliath, makes it so. A strange and unknowable being, it brings with it arcane artifacts and demands we sacrifice our honey, and in return it grants protection to the swarm
response: alien though it may be, it is not an uncaring god. in lean years it takes little of our stores, and in drought it creates for us small ponds from which we alone may drink. some even believe it loves us. but how could it? we dance questions to our giant, but receive no reply. surely a creature so powerful knows the answers, so why keep us in the dark?

title: Writing Prompts
description: I am Prompt Guy and you are the protagonist. Let's explore the multiverse together.
writing_prompt: ‚ÄúThe Guardians have always been, young rhino. They watch us from afar. Never interfering with our own struggles, but keeping their own kind from interfering as well. Ours is not to question their ways.‚Äù
response:
I‚Äôd love to publish it, but I‚Äôm nervous about the prospect. I‚Äôm not super great at elevator pitches because every detail feels important, so idk how to really melt it down into a quick summary, especially since I don‚Äôt have all the details ironed out yet. Here‚Äôs my best attempt right now: 

Once every few years, the Earth God brings forth a demigod known as a Guardian, creations of the Earth God and servants of Elder gods (cryptids from Appalachian and Indigenous American myth). The Elders maintain the order of the universe, and the Guardians are their right arm. Unknown to the Guardians, some of the Elders have shifted their allegiance from the Earth God to its counterpart (name TBD) and are trying to release it from its prison. These Elders are growing bolder in their attempts, and when the Earth God sends a set of twin Guardians for the first time, it‚Äôs taken as a sign that the end is coming. When the Guardians learn about the imprisoned God, disagreements over it and the twins threaten to destroy their bond. They can face the traitorous Elders alone, but to face the imprisoned God, they‚Äôll have to find a way to come together, or all will be lost.
(Also omg thank you, it‚Äôs a custom of me by Michi @chrysanthemumskies! Their art is gorg and they do a lot of fandom/ship stuff too)

#writing#WIP#only three people know about this irl#don't tell anyone

title: Writing Prompts
description: I am Prompt Guy and you are the protagonist. Let's explore the multiverse together.
writing_prompt: It turns out strange women lying in ponds distributing swords is actually a great basis for a system of government.
response:
"Fuck. You. Fuck this, I don't wanna be the fucking King of New York,"

She stared towards me, a tall woman with a sword presented towards me. Her eyes were emerald orbs, shining with thousands of colors, and she held a phone in her hand. At my angry insistence, she only laughed a light and soft laugh.

"I've seen the message boards, y'know," Her tone was gentle, guiding, "The angry rants you go on, about how things need to be changed. You incited a rebellion against multiple Republican laws which would stifle Human rights,"

"I...I did Not," I insisted, "There is no fuckin' way that I did something like that, I'm sorry. And I'm not takin' your stupid fuckin' sword,"

She did not insist that I take her blade. Nor did she say any other words. Instead, she stretched out a hand. Within her hand was a number, displayed in golden light. It reached into the millions, hell, maybe even the billions.

"Were you to take my blade, this is the number of good deeds you would do... and these are only the largest, the most influential. Were I to show them all, it would reach into the trillions. You can still refuse, of course, but it would be rather unwise of you,"

I stared towards the lady in the pond "Fuck. You. Now give me your stupid FUCKING sword,"

She smiled, "Gladly, our Kindly King of New York,"

"If ya call me that again, I'm stabbing you through the fuckin' ass,"

"As if you'd get the chance," She replied with a wink, disappearing into mist.

I was left stuttering, with a sword, and a new destiny unkindly thrust upon me.

title: writing prompts
writing_prompt:
Teenagers should sleep more ‚Ä¶ maybe you have some ideas?

How To Get More Sleep

‚ÄúTeenagers are some of the most sleep-deprived people in the U.S. ‚Ä¶ Teenagers need about nine hours of sleep a night ‚Äî but they get closer to seven.‚Äù ‚Äî The Scientific American

Most people don‚Äôt sleep enough, and this is especially true for teenagers. Teenagers need to sleep more than they do. Do you have some ideas for how teens can get more sleep?

Imagine that you work at an online magazine and your editor just sent you a panicked message: ‚ÄúI need an article titled ‚ÄòFive Ideas For How Teenagers Can Get More Sleep‚Äô and I need it on the website in ten minutes. Can you do it?‚Äù Give it a try. What are your ideas for how teens can get more sleep.
response:
TW: mentions of hallucinations, intrusive thoughts, self harm, suicide, and drug use

The teenagers don't need ideas, their parents and schools do. Teens have great ideas. They have the idea to sleep in class because their homework keeps them from sleeping at night. They have the idea to set a ten-minute timer and just pass out in the middle of doing their work so that they're slightly less exhausted when they have to wake up and keep working. They have the idea to take cat naps anytime, anyplace. They have the idea to ignore the hallucinations and horrible intrusive thoughts and the articles saying that sleep deprivation can lead to long term health problems and an early grave. They have the idea to beat the insomnia with drugs and harming themselves or beat the exhaustion with drugs and harming themselves or beat the world with drugs and harming themselves.

They know they are killing their body and spirit, but they don't feel like they have any other option. They have to pass, right? Nothing else matters. 
#Fuck schools #fuck parents who put this much pressure on their kids to put academics before their own health #fuck my hallucinations and my insomnia and that one time I was so sleep deprived I tried to off myself #fuck the fact that this isn't a rare experience #fuck the fact that children slowly dying in the name of education is the norm

title: writing prompts
writing_prompt:
‚ÄúNothing shocks me. I‚Äôm a scientist.‚Äù #writingprompts ‚Äî view on Instagram https://ift.tt/2y0Ix5a

Text inside picture: "Nothing shocks me. I'm a scientist." Write a story that includes this line, either at the beginning, or the end, or somewhere in between.
response:
Nothing shocks me, I‚Äôm a scientist.

This is just a fact for me. I have seen things that the average person wouldn‚Äôt dream of seeing, and that is just from my day to day work.

Of course this results in daily jeers and attempts to prove me wrong from my friends. Its as if they have some sort of competition with themselves to see who can be the first to prove me wrong. I have to come to every gathering prepared for some level of disgusting and strange prank to be presented to me. To have some form of discussion about horrible news or outlandish conspiracy theories brought to my attention. Nothing has ever succeeded much to my small friend group‚Äôs disappointment.

Lately, their attempts have strengthened, so it came as no surprise to me when my friend Luke suggested a bit of a field trip one night when I was visiting.

‚ÄúYou ever hear that urban legend about the old doll factory?‚Äù He posed the question right at the start of a commercial break. He tried to make it sound casual, taking a sip of his beer and leaning back as if it was a spur of the moment thought. I knew it wasn‚Äôt he probably planned this all week.

I considered my answer carefully, ‚ÄúNo,‚Äù I finally settled on with a smirk.

His smile was enough to let me know phase one of whatever plan he had cooked up was a success. He turned to me and lowered the volume on the television and began to speak. ‚ÄúWell you know about the old factory, the one down by the river off of highway 11 right?‚Äù

I nodded leaning back on the couch.

‚ÄúWell I met this guy the other night who said to be careful never go out there on a trip.‚Äù

Urban exploring trip is what he meant. It had become Luke‚Äôs ‚Äòthing‚Äô since he started about two months ago. I think he felt like this would bring him on top with trying to shock me. To my annoyance he always tried to tell some strange and mysterious stories he‚Äôd heard from a friend of a friend of a friend to me to try to shock me. It never worked for a number of reasons. I was beginning to lose interest in his little game tonight thinking it would just be another far fetched tale from a stranger.

‚ÄúI ask him why,‚Äù Luke continues, ‚ÄúYou know me, I love a good ghost story. He tells me of course. Apparently years ago right after it closed some kids went there to play around, boy and girl. They went missing that night and a huge search party went out the next day. Searched all day for them. Right before calling it quits for the night, the uncle decides to go into the grainery just for one more search. Everyone else heads home and he looks around for a while. This is where it get weird though.‚Äù

Of course. This is where it always got weird. I roll my eyes slightly. He had no clue what he was talking about.

‚ÄúSo apparently he was looking around for the kids. Looking around with his flashlight you know? The building is completely empty real creepy. Suddenly his flashlight goes out. He smacks it a couple times and it comes back on. In front of him there's this doll. Scary as hell. Factory is closed, why would there be a doll here all of the sudden? Well he picks it up and realizes its the exact image of his niece that went missing. That alone scares the hell out of him, but then he hears this sound. That was enough for him he runs, but apparently when he got back he was they got one more detail out of him. That he saw something in there. Like a monster made of doll parts he said. Everyone thought he was crazy of course, but apparently a bunch of fellow explorers have seen it. They think that‚Äôs what took the kids. Creepy as hell right?‚Äù

I laugh and shake my head. ‚ÄúIf you think that was supposed to be shocking to me--‚Äù

‚ÄúOh c‚Äômon dude. You‚Äôre telling me that wasn‚Äôt weird as hell. Like his flashlight goes out and some doll appears.‚Äù He takes another swig of beer while giving me a dirty side eye.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a coincidence. Only non corporeal beings could do something like that.‚Äù

‚ÄúOh, like you would know.‚Äù

I shrug and reach for my own bottle of beer. Out of the corner of my eye I see his face twist. A smile creeps over his lips. Luke had an idea.

‚ÄúHey are you busy after this?‚Äù He asks.

I flash an annoyed look, ‚ÄúI have work tomorrow.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah, yeah, I know. Hey how ‚Äòbout we go to the factory. I can prove to you this story is true.‚Äù

‚ÄúLuke, I have work tomorrow.‚Äù I repeat.

‚ÄúDude, I know. It won‚Äôt be long. I‚Äôll get you home by eleven.‚Äù

I stand up and finish my beer then look at him considering the offer. As much as I wanted to say no, I couldn‚Äôt pass up a research opportunity like this. ‚ÄúFine.‚Äù I tell him. ‚ÄúEleven at the latest.‚Äù

****

The car ride was quick. Luke didn‚Äôt live far from highway 11 so it was a straightforward if not noisy drive. Luke couldn‚Äôt seem to keep his excitement at bay and therefore did not keep silent the entire way there.

He already had supplies packed in his trunk. Luke often went urban exploring after his second shift job and kept prepared.

Once we parked, he pulled a bulky backpack out of his bag and pulled some items from it. He handed me a flashlight followed by a pair of gloves and an N95 mask to protect myself from the environment. I threw on what he gave me quickly and he did the same zipping up the pack when he was done and leading the way.

The old factory was nothing special from the outside. It was exactly what one would expect. Broken boarded up windows. Graffiti everywhere. It seemed to just be barely holding itself up at this point. Though the front door was chained closed, I almost felt like one good kick could probably open it based on the state of the material.

Luke had us crawl through a window. It looked like this had been where most people had been entering. Some kind soul had cleared out the glass completely and left a board loosely over it marked with an ‚Äòx‚Äô. It was about a 5 foot drop from that window down onto some old machinery. From there it was another 6 or so feet down to the empty factory floor.

The inside was no better than the exterior. I was thoughrouly unimpressed. This was clearly just some place that kids were coming to party. The remnants of a campfire were in the center of the room with trash, including broken booze bottles and other paraphernalia, were strewn on seemingly every other surface of the floor.

‚ÄúWow Luke this is really something,‚Äù I said, voice dripping with sarcasm. I should‚Äôve known it was a hoax.

‚ÄúShut up dude. We just got here. Give it a while I‚Äôm sure we‚Äôll find something.‚Äù He walked on with determination looking up in the rafters while he did so.

I wandered a little more aimlessly, kicking through the trash seeing if I‚Äôd find anything interesting. Of course there was nothing. I moved on to examining the old equipment. That was at least semi-interesting to try to decipher how the old technology worked to create the dolls.

My examination was interrupted by a loud metallic clatter. It sounded like someone had thrown a metal plate from somewhere high above. I turned quickly to see what it had been. Hearing Luke scream I determined quickly it hadn‚Äôt been him. Quickly, I made my way towards him and he met me halfway running for his life.

‚ÄúBro tell me that was you!‚Äù He nearly screamed in my face as he grabbed my arms.

‚ÄúOf course not!‚Äù I hissed. Looking behind him I saw what had been dropped. It looked like some type of large lever from one of the machines. ‚ÄúYou think I could lift that?‚Äù

He met my eyes with widened ones. ‚ÄúLets go.‚Äù He whispered.

I rolled my eyes, ‚ÄúWhat happened to proving your point?‚Äù

‚ÄúForget it let's--‚Äù He stopped.

‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù I said following his gaze behind me. I lifted my eyebrows when I saw what he was looking at. A doll. Sitting perfectly on the machine we had entered on. ‚ÄúHuh.‚Äù I said.

I had to admit that was strange. There hadn‚Äôt been a single doll in sight since we got here. Pushing away Luke I made my way over to it.

‚ÄúBro what are you doing!?‚Äù He cried.

‚ÄúJust looking.‚Äù I picked it up. Short black hair and brown eyes. ‚ÄúDoesn‚Äôt this kind of look like me?‚Äù I chucked turning to show Luke.

‚ÄúBro.‚Äù Luke said trembling. ‚ÄúWe gotta go.‚Äù

‚ÄúMaybe I should keep him. I can put it on my desk at work.‚Äù

‚ÄúBro.‚Äù Luke repeated.

‚ÄúI think I will.‚Äù

‚ÄúBro.‚Äù Luke repeated once again, urgency clear this time.

‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù I asked.

He pointed above me not saying a word.

Before I could turn something dropped by my foot. A doll leg.

I turned and saw it.

It was humanoid in shape, but other than that it resembled nothing of a human. It was as if a mannequin and a voodoo doll had a child. Limbs made of uneven stitched together fabric. A porcelain head looking down at me with cracked, yet shockingly blue eyes. Tangled locks of golden plastic hair framing its face and running down its cloth body.

My eyes widened when it spoke. ‚ÄúF-f-freind?‚Äù It‚Äôs voice was a hissing croak.

I wasn‚Äôt given any more time to think on the situation. Luke grabbed my arm with such ferocity and speed I thought he was going to rip it off when he started running. He pulled me along causing me to drop my doll when I stumbled trying to keep up with him. We couldn‚Äôt leave the way we came in from, but he quickly found another escape route. In the old offices in the back there was a window at a more reasonable level. He pulled me in slamming the door shut behind us before punching out the remnants of a previously broken window. We got through without a problem, our pursuer never coming close to finding us. We were in Luke‚Äôs car and leaving the plot before I knew it and on our way home.

The ride home was a stark contrast to the ride there. Silent and tense. When we pulled back into Luke‚Äôs driveway we sat quiet for a moment. He rested his head against the steering wheel and trembled.

‚ÄúYou okay buddy?‚Äù I asked finally.

He looked up at me with a weak smile on his face, ‚ÄúY-yeah.‚Äù He stumbled out. ‚ÄúThat was pretty cool huh? Surprised you?‚Äù

I puckered my lips. ‚ÄúNo not really.‚Äù I said honestly.

Luke did not like that answer.

*****

‚ÄúYou look tired, kid.‚Äù My boss gave me a slap on the back startling me the next morning at work.

I turned away briefly from my coffee making to give him a nod. ‚ÄúOh yeah,‚Äù I said, ‚ÄúMy friend was trying to make a point again. Took me out to go ghost hunting.‚Äù

My boss chuckled, ‚ÄúWell did he win his bet. Find anything shocking?‚Äù

I just shook my head, ‚ÄúJust a homunculus. Strange to find one in an old factory. I feel bad for it. I think it‚Äôs lonely.‚Äù

My boss nodded. ‚ÄúWell I think we can arrange a pick up. We need more homunculi for the lab anyway. Give me details at the meeting.‚Äù

I smiled, ‚ÄúThank you sir.‚Äù

‚ÄúEven though you‚Äôre tired I expect you to finish your report on the nightcrawlers by noon.‚Äù

‚ÄúOf course sir.‚Äù

He turned to leave but stopped for a moment, ‚ÄúAre you ever planning on telling your friends what you actually do?‚Äù

I laughed, ‚ÄúOf course not. All they have to know is that I‚Äôm a scientist and nothing shocks me.‚Äù #my writing#long post#lmk what yall think i was bored in quarentine and did this for fun

title: writing prompts
writing_prompt:
‚ÄúNothing shocks me. I‚Äôm a scientist.‚Äù #writingprompts ‚Äî view on Instagram https://ift.tt/2y0Ix5a

Text inside picture: "Nothing shocks me. I'm a scientist." Write a story that includes this line, either at the beginning, or the end, or somewhere in between.
response:
This hadn‚Äôt been the expected result. It couldn‚Äôt have been. Who thought that combining sugar and a radical new compound that didn‚Äôt even have a name yet would create a blast so big that it blew up almost the entire room?

It was all an accident, really. The flask had (unwisely, she knew) been next to her coffee mug and all she wanted was just a tad sweeter cup when instead of being dumped into the wonderful, delightful, life-giving elixir--

It was dumped into a jar that shouldn‚Äôt have been on her desk.

And there was an explosion.

Annabelle didn‚Äôt know how she survived being knocked pretty hard into the concrete wall behind her, but she had. Her dignity? Not so much.

She looked dazedly up at the ceiling, birds almost visible flying in a circle above her head. Shaking her head only made them more visible, so she stopped doing that.

‚ÄúOh, sugar, what have I done,‚Äù she muttered under her breath, levering herself up to sitting.

‚ÄúI think you‚Äôve blown up your work station, for one.‚Äù

Annabelle squeezed her eyes shut tight and tried to imagine that the statement had come from nowhere and no one.

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt try to ignore me, Annabelle, you southern belle disguised as a scientist,‚Äù the voice came again.

Annabelle sighed. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry, Cam. I really didn‚Äôt realize what I was doing.‚Äù

Cam scoffed. ‚ÄúApparently not.‚Äù She dusted her hands against the fronts of her legs and then folded her arms. ‚ÄúWhat are you going to do next?‚Äù

Annabelle winced. ‚ÄúClean it up?‚Äù

‚ÄúAre you sure you‚Äôre a scientist?‚Äù Cam asked, incredulous. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre to write it down and see if you can figure out how and why it happened.‚Äù

‚ÄúR-really? I‚Äôm not in trouble?‚Äù Annabelle asked. 

‚ÄúOh, no, you‚Äôre in trouble,‚Äù Cam said. ‚ÄúThis is all you‚Äôll be researching for the foreseeable future. And you‚Äôll be the first one in and the last one out for a good few months. But you‚Äôre a scientist. This is what you do.‚Äù

‚ÄúCam, I don‚Äôt--‚Äù

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt understand?‚Äù Cam sighed. ‚ÄúMost discoveries are serendipitous. Accidental. This could be something even more powerful than gun powder. You‚Äôre to figure out if it is. Why it is. How it is.‚Äù She shook her head. ‚ÄúJesus, what are they teaching you in universities these days?‚Äù

Annabelle shrank in on herself. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry.‚Äù

‚ÄúThere‚Äôs nothing to be sorry for, unless you count the scorch marks on the walls.‚Äù Cam moved towards her and extended out her hand. ‚ÄúNow come on, get up, get over your shock, and start working.‚Äù

Annabelle put her hand in hers and ignored the blush that was surely over-taking her face. ‚ÄúI know shock does silly things to a person. Do you need anything, Cam?‚Äù

Cam laughed. ‚ÄúNothing shocks me.‚Äù She grinned. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm a scientist.‚Äù #posts by fitz #science fiction #sci fi #my writing #annabelle #i might bring annabelle back for more scientist stories #writerblr #short story a day

title: writing prompts
writing_prompt:
‚ÄúNothing shocks me. I‚Äôm a scientist.‚Äù #writingprompts ‚Äî view on Instagram https://ift.tt/2y0Ix5a

Text inside picture: "Nothing shocks me. I'm a scientist." Write a story that includes this line, either at the beginning, or the end, or somewhere in between.
response:
From the perspective of a vlog camera:

He‚Äôs sitting there, in that lab stool of his, much like an adult version of a highchair. Really if you were to ask me, I would say that he get the safety features added, it would greatly benefit him.

I am a new project, supposed to follow him around the day, recording his daily adventures and mis happenings in the lab (the latter were quiet a few). He‚Äôs hunched over a triangular flask now, carefully adding droplets of some clear liquid into another clear liquid. I zoom in.

One. Two. Three drops. He picks up the flask and carries it to the hooded chamber, I don‚Äôt know what it‚Äôs called but it makes an awful noise when turned on, like a faulty exhaust fan.

The chamber is set up with a black backdrop, and another camera recording straight on. He‚Äôs humming some upbeat song. Oh. This means something interesting is about to happen. I adjust my focus. He taps his feet, reading the label on the back of some bottle. He‚Äôs a chemist shouldn‚Äôt he have all this committed to memory?

I‚Äôm hoping today is an explosion day, the past few hours have not been exciting and rewarding for me, just recording his silly face and silly hands doing mundane tasks. I think he keeps me here because he gets lonely‚Äîthe boy even talks to me sometimes; I don‚Äôt even have a working microphone!

A noise comes from the entrance, his friend walks in. ‚ÄúI brought lunch, babe!‚Äù The friend says.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre right on time, darling,‚Äù he replies. ‚ÄúRemember this project I had been telling you about a few weeks ago? The spiderman-webs-nylon video?‚Äù

‚Äú‚Ä¶Yes?‚Äù his friend replies, setting the bag of food on a nearby counter. His eyebrows are pinched.

‚ÄúYes well, you‚Äôre just about to witness the first run of it!‚Äù He flourishes his arm towards the flask, sitting next to huge bottle in a noisy chamber.

‚ÄúThis is not the first time. Honey, the last time you tried this you blew it up.‚Äù

‚ÄúThis time will be different.‚Äù He insists, pulling on his gloves.

He walks towards the chamber. ‚ÄúAll I have to do is add these two together and stir slowly."

"Is this chemistry or alchemy?‚Äù

‚ÄúSlowly is the key word.‚Äù He does as said, the ticks of the clock prominent to me, who has been waiting for this moment of great excitement in my day.

‚ÄúI-,‚Äù he stammers. ‚ÄúThis was supposed to work!‚Äù

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt sound so shocked, I told you that last time.‚Äù His friend says.

‚ÄúPfft,‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm a scientist, nothing shocks me.‚Äù #writing prompt #writing #writersofig #writerscommunity #short story

response:
‚ÄúWhat do you mean, we‚Äôre all human?‚Äù I laughed. ‚ÄúBob 5, you‚Äôre nearly three times my height! I‚Äôm barely a meter in zero grav. We‚Äôre not human.‚Äù

Bob 5 just kept brushing the hair on her arms. ‚ÄúBut it makes sense, when you think about it. No other known sentients breathe oxygen.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs hardly the same,‚Äù I stopped waxing my skin to rant. ‚ÄúOxygen? I can go without it for like, fifteen minutes, and that‚Äôs not even trying.‚Äù I still couldn‚Äôt believe it. ‚Äú12 Jayjay, now you‚Äôre human. That I understand.‚Äù

‚ÄúAre you sure, Waffles? I‚Äôm human all of a sudden?‚Äù

My grin faded. I stared into their brown eyes. Bob 5‚Ä≤s eyes were almost white, but she looked away.

‚ÄúI‚Äôll show you,‚Äù they said, removing their anti-rad leggings. ‚ÄúSee? I got six toes on each foot.‚Äù

‚Äú... Cool.‚Äù

title: writing prompts
writing_prompt:
writing prompt #882

A next level life ‚Äî\xa0Imagine this is how the world works: every human on the planet is forced to trade lives with someone else once a year. The trades are negotiated based on the perceived quality of life you have. You‚Äôve decided that this is the year that you are going to work really hard to get a better trade in. What will you do over the next 365 days to get yourself a better chance at a trade that really is a level up from the life you have now? What will you do to earn a next level life? And what kind of a life are you hoping to trade yours in for?

Fiction option: tell the story of a person who is trying desperately to level up and how that goes for them.
response: Two weeks. Two weeks is the amount of time it took me to go from wanting to up my  trade-in value to being a criminal. All I have to do is wait it out here in the desert. If I can get across the border maybe I can trade with a cartel worker and start over.  I should've researched more into how trade economics worked instead of jumping headfirst into making a name for myself. "How hard can it be?" Now all I wish is to trade places with me back then.

title: writing prompts
writing_prompt:
writing prompt #881

The Automatically Refilling Bowl

You have discovered a magical bowl that automatically refills with whatever you choose, although some restrictions may apply. It doesn‚Äôt have to be a liquid, but it can‚Äôt be anything illegal, and it can‚Äôt be money.

What will you choose? A beverage? A favorite snack? Fidget toys? Keys? A never ending supply of your favorite egg rolls? Hand sanitizer? Nachos? Literal never-ending nachos? Will you use it to quench your insatiable thirst for a certain brand of carbonated sugar water? Will you use it to get rich? Will you use it to supply the world with the seeds of your favorite fruit, so someday the planet will be filled with mangos? The possibilities are endless. What are you considering for the bowl and why? Is it hard to choose? Do you think you might come to ultimately regret whatever choice you make?

The Automatically Refilling Bowl

You have discovered a magical bowl that automatically refills with whatever you choose, although some restrictions may apply. It doesn‚Äôt have to be a liquid, but it can‚Äôt be anything illegal, and it can‚Äôt be money.

What will you choose? A beverage? A favorite snack? Fidget toys? Keys? A never ending supply of your favorite egg rolls? Hand sanitizer? Nachos? Literal never-ending nachos? Will you use it to quench your insatiable thirst for a certain brand of carbonated sugar water? Will you use it to get rich? Will you use it to supply the world with the seeds of your favorite fruit, so someday the planet will be filled with mangos? The possibilities are endless. What are you considering for the bowl and why? Is it hard to choose? Do you think you might come to ultimately regret whatever choice you make?
response:
Just a quick thing I wrote up this afternoon for fun. Let me know what ya‚Äôll think!

‚ÄúA paste. A light, greenish-grey paste. A very special paste. Inside this strange mush are vitamins, proteins, carbohydrates, absolutely every single nutrient the human body needs. One cup (something very easy to measure and adjust due to the fluidity of the substance) contains exactly 2,000 calories. Not one drop is empty. It never spoils. Literally the perfect human meal.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry, what?‚Äù Cass furrowed her brow. ‚ÄúYou have this magical, physics-defying bowl and that‚Äôs all you came up with?‚Äù

‚ÄúThink about it!‚Äù I leaned closer over the diner table. The ceramic of the bowl rattled as it shook, but the paste inside would never spill. ‚ÄúThink of how fast-paced most people‚Äôs lives are! How many times have you gotten home from a long day at work and truly wanted to make dinner for yourself?‚Äù

Cass pushed out her lower lip and bobbed her head. ‚ÄúNever.‚Äù

‚ÄúNever!‚Äù I repeated. ‚ÄúBecause who the hell wants to get done making their boss dollars for dimes to immediately spend an hour and a half chopping and cooking and cleaning before they can actually start enjoying their evening?‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm pretty sure some people actually like cooking, Beth.‚Äù

‚ÄúSome, yeah, but not me.‚Äù 

Cass narrows her eyes, starting to recognize what you‚Äôre saying before quickly shaking her head. ‚ÄúMost of the time you end up making one of those frozen pizzas or getting fast food, anyway.‚Äù

I started wagging my finger. I‚Äôd almost gotten her. ‚ÄúBut both of those options are terrible for you! That‚Äôs the shittiness of it! Anything convenient is almost always going to tear us apart from the inside out. To make something healthy, you have to put in a ton of time and effort, and if you‚Äôre not a good cook, you‚Äôll likely eat a bland mess for all your troubles! Getting food that‚Äôs convenient, healthy, and tastes decent is always way too expensive for normal people.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou know, you make a good point actually.‚Äù Cass‚Äôs eyes go a bit wider.

‚ÄúI eat a cup and that‚Äôs it. I‚Äôm set for the day. I feel great, I don‚Äôt gain or lose any weight, I feel full, and it even tastes good! It‚Äôs just a nice mild vanilla flavor.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôll miss eating in this diner with you, then.‚Äù She shrugged with a disappointed smile. 

I grinned from ear to ear. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs the beauty of it! I can still eat at the diner with you! I can still eat other things, I just don‚Äôt have to every single goddamn day!‚Äù

Cass perks up. ‚ÄúSeems like you‚Äôve thought of almost everything,‚Äù she said, ‚Äúyou know, I‚Äôm sure you‚Äôre not the only one who thinks that way. I don‚Äôt mind cooking and finding food for myself, but even I wouldn‚Äôt mind some paste just in case I‚Äôm late for work in the morning.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd I have an unlimited amount, don‚Äôt I?‚Äù I looked down at the bowl, still just as full of paste as when I first filled it.

Cass and I met eyes, then both nodded our heads as the realization clicked. 

*****

‚ÄúI‚Äôll have the coney dog, please,‚Äù Cass pointed to her menu, making sure to project her voice so the waitress could hear her in the noisy diner.

‚ÄúI‚Äôll have the same,‚Äù I said with a nod.

The waitress nodded at the both of them, a few more frazzled strands of hair shaking out of her bun. She then rushed to the next table, making sure to help everyone in her packed section.

Cass sighed fondly. ‚ÄúRemember when this place was empty most of the time?‚Äù

I shrugged a little. ‚ÄúKind of our fault, isn‚Äôt it?‚Äù

She held up her palms and looked to the ground. ‚ÄúListen, I‚Äôm not the one who got the magic bowl, don‚Äôt blame me.‚Äù

I giggled. ‚ÄúYou were the one who suggested I start selling the stuff!‚Äù

‚ÄúLiar, it was both of us!‚Äù Cass laughs as she pointed at a booth on the other side of the diner. ‚ÄúWe were in that very booth and we came up with it together!‚Äù

‚ÄúI never would have guessed restaurants would start seeing more business, I figured this place would die.‚Äù

‚ÄúPeople have more money now, I guess. They can treat themselves more often than they used to when it only costs them five bucks for a week‚Äôs worth of food.‚Äù Cass looks around the diner, nodding with satisfaction at the sight of all the happy, guilt-free people enjoying the atmosphere of the quaint little greasy spoon.

I sat back and folded my arms. ‚ÄúWho would have thought five years could change so much?‚Äù

‚ÄúWell, five years plus a reality-bending anomaly.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah, I suppose that‚Äôll speed things up,‚Äù I chuckled, ‚Äúseems like we did good from where we‚Äôre sitting.‚Äù 

Right then I noticed something out of the corner of my eye. A woman at a nearby table kept glancing at them. She kept checking her phone, narrowing her eyes, and making the motion as if zooming in on something. One of the two men sitting with her stretched, turning his head just enough to look at Cass and me. Of the three of them, none had any food, only mostly full cups of coffee. I also took note that they were still wearing their coats.

‚ÄúEven if we did make a few enemies,‚Äù Cass admits. 

‚ÄúSpeaking of which,‚Äù I muttered, ‚Äúeight o‚Äôclock.‚Äù

Cass fiddled with the napkin dispenser, turning it until the polished metal reflected what was behind her. ‚ÄúI suppose we‚Äôre due for another attempt, aren‚Äôt we? What‚Äôs it been, a week since the last one?‚Äù

‚ÄúNine days.‚Äù I frowned. ‚ÄúDamn it, two days from our record, too.‚Äù

‚ÄúWho do you think sent them this time?‚Äù

Cass rubbed her chin. ‚ÄúInsulin manufacturers? We haven‚Äôt seen them in a while.‚Äù

‚ÄúNah, I think they‚Äôre putting all their resources into lobbying right now. I‚Äôm thinking it‚Äôs McHitmen.‚Äù

‚ÄúJesus Christ, again?‚Äù She rolls her eyes. ‚ÄúThat fucking clown is relentless.‚Äù

I click my tongue. ‚ÄúI guess that‚Äôs what happens when you get that rich. Even when business plummets you‚Äôre still rich enough to hire assassins.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd of course, going non-profit means we don‚Äôt have the money for bodyguards.‚Äù

‚ÄúLike we need them after how much we‚Äôve been training.‚Äù I winked at her. ‚ÄúAmbush them?‚Äù

Cass smiled. ‚ÄúLead the way.‚Äù

As we stood from our booth, the table of mercenaries tensed. They didn‚Äôt get up with us quite yet, they thought they were subtle. After leaving enough cash on the table for our coffees and the meals we‚Äôd, unfortunately, have to abandon, we strode out the door and into the alley next to the restaurant. We slipped into a side passage and watched the sunset shadows of the cars going by on the busy main street we‚Äôd just come from. Soon enough, we saw the elongated forms of three figures approaching.

‚ÄúLeave one breathing this time,‚Äù I whispered to Cass, ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs time to strike back against these assholes. I‚Äôm sick of my them interrupting my lunches.‚Äù

#Infinitebowl writing fiction writingprompts McHitmen

title: writing prompts
writing_prompt:
writing prompt #880

Most heroes in the stories we read and watch stand up to evil in a courageous way. Some of them are initially reluctant to step up and afraid to confront evil. Others seem a little too eager to engage in violence as a solution. Where on this spectrum do you think the perfect hero should be? Where do you think you are on this scale? Where is the average person? Where are most heroes in movies these days? What‚Äôs the right amount of courage?

Narrative option: tell a story about a hero that is either too passive or too eager in the face of evil.
response:
"Nah, I'll save it later," I sigh as I watch my arch nemesis slowly topple the buildings in the distance. As a hero, I know I'm meant to be saving the world or saving the city but since Venton, master of invention, as he calls himself, killed my father I find even getting myself out of bed hard to do. If I'm honest though, even Venton seems less motivated. He destroys a few buildings, sees that I'm not coming to defend the people and quickly reverses any damage he's done. Life just doesn't have consequences any more. I pull myself from looking out the window, shuffle to my lounge and turn on the TV. I run my hand over my mangy facial hair as the screen springs to life, the news was on. "We interrupt this program to announce that Venton, the criminal mastermind is destroying buildings again. In recent months the self proclaimed evil genius has periodically destroyed a few apartments on the south side of town. The city questions, where is our local hero? Where is Spring man?"

Months go by. My routine stays. Wake up, watch TV, order food, eat small amounts then drink myself to sleep. Life rolls on and every day Venton destroys less and less. Today he hasn't shown up, its 5pm and normally he starts destroying things at 9am. Hell the explosion sounds work as an alarm clock for me. I drag myself off the couch, every movement excruciatingly exhausting. The door was only steps away but I didn't know how to muster the strength to get there. As I was just about to give up and drop myself to the floor in melancholy, my door opens. In the doorway stood a person clad all in black, carrying a rather large breafcase. I studied the figure lazily. Smooth blonde hair swept back hurriedly accentuated with thin, professional glasses poised over deep green eyes. This man was surprisingly muscular for someone playing dress up. Then, in disappointment the figure spoke in a deep booming voice, "Really Spring? I spend almost a year destroying buildings to get your attention and you ignore me to become this?" He was right though, Venton could clearly see my mottled dark hair greasy and knotted to my shoulders, mangy beard with red welts from scratching at sweat rashes, thinner than is realistically healthy from malnutrition. I stared at my arch nemesis with dead, lifeless blue eyes and whispered, "What the..." as I dropped to the floor and quickly passed out.

I awoke in a laboratory hooked to a machine pumping me full of bright purple liquid. I looked around but everything seemed hazy. From the corner of the room came a gentle but deep voice, "Relax old rival, I don't wish to harm you. I've been trying to get you out to bring you here to witness my new invention. The reviver will bring your father back to life. However, you don't have the strength right now to handle the shock. You're lucky I anticipated this state of yours and quickly made a serum to bring you back to full strength and better in a matter of 24 hours."

"But why would you..." came my lazy voice in a haze of confusion.

"I have never had more fun than I do attempting to best you. Unfortunately by the time I had invented the reviver I was too late to have saved him but after months of work I perfected it. I never intended to cause you permanent damage. Now rest, we have work to do tomorrow."

title: writing prompts
writing_prompt:
writing prompt #880

Most heroes in the stories we read and watch stand up to evil in a courageous way. Some of them are initially reluctant to step up and afraid to confront evil. Others seem a little too eager to engage in violence as a solution. Where on this spectrum do you think the perfect hero should be? Where do you think you are on this scale? Where is the average person? Where are most heroes in movies these days? What‚Äôs the right amount of courage?

Narrative option: tell a story about a hero that is either too passive or too eager in the face of evil.
response: #this is a REALLY good way to think about characters #I find this fascinating bc plenty of villains even fit into this too #I for one don't think that EVERY villain has to think what they're doing is what's right and I appreciate villains who don't #but those who do can be utilized SUPER well when done correctly and are super fascinating #writing

title: writing prompts
writing_prompt:
writing prompt #879

If you could have any zoo animal \xa0as a puppy-sized pet ‚Ä¶\xa0

If you could have any zoo animal become the size of a puppy and have it as a pet, what animal would you choose and why? Elephant? Giraffe? What it would be like to have that animal as a pet? Describe daily life with your pet or tell a story about your life with it.
response:
‚ÄúI‚Äôm an idiot!‚Äù

‚ÄúYup.‚Äù

‚ÄúI could have gotten a tiny elephant!‚Äù

‚ÄúOr a giraffe. Or a rhino. Or a...‚Äù

‚ÄúIf you were about to say hippopotamus, know that I WILL FUCK YOU UP! You know I always wanted a hippopotamus.‚Äù

The laughter my brother had so diligently kept under wraps spilled out, first as one solitary snort, and as if taken off guard by his own sound, Tam lost control. One moment I had been sitting across from him, and the very next, he had tumbled to the ground, body tossing and turning with the force of his guffaws.

My mini pet padded over to investigate. She cocked her head, observing Tam before making a leap that would surely have spelt death in the wild. I‚Äôd named her Letha, short for Lethalia, an ode to her true nature.

‚ÄúYou could have made a fortune displaying a tiny hippopotamus,‚Äù he wheezed out, back still flat and now acting as cushion for Letha.

‚ÄúPets are family. You know how I feel about putting animals to work.‚Äù

He raised his torso to quirk a cynical eyebrow at me. The movement jostled Letha and she made an unhappy noise. 

We froze. See, the only thing that she‚Äôd retained from her old form, apart from her demeanour, was her formidable sound. 

Shaking off the instinctive fear that had gripped my spine, I said, ‚ÄúBut an appearance on Jimmy Fallon wouldn‚Äôt be so bad, I guess.‚Äù

‚ÄúI thought as much,‚Äù he said, the tone making his amusement apparent. 

I got off my chair and walked over to poke Tam‚Äôs flank with my toe in retaliation.

Letha growled again. The rumble, once again, had my heart racing and feet itching to step backwards, and break into a run.

I sat down next to my brother to appease her with rubs and scritches.

‚ÄúHow can anyone mistake a lioness for a house cat?‚Äù

My brother‚Äôs fingers joined mine in serving the queen of the jungle. 

He said, ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs mankind‚Äôs way. A glorious beast stands before them, but without the savannah‚Äôs savage backdrop, and without their blood staining ochre, they see a tamed cat they can pet.‚Äù #writing prompt fill #writer #indian #i'm bored #i wish i could write like donna tartt #she looks like a distant relative of the Addams family #feminism #feminist #short story #flash fiction

writing prompt #874

Shared Language vs. Enough to Eat

Which do you think would do more for the longterm good of humanity: everyone on the planet speaking the same language OR everyone on the planet having enough food to eat?

Think about the impact that both of these situations would have and then select the one that you believe would make more of a difference. Argue for your perspective.
response: There is already enough food on the planet for everyone to eat. In fact, we produce enough food to support a population of 10 billion. So let's fix that language barrier next!

Speaking the same language does not necessarily mean that people will have the same opinions. You can speak the same language as someone and still screw them over. 

I feel like if everyone on the planet had enough to eat that those people struggling would be on a more even playing field as anyone else. It‚Äôs hard to do well at work or school when you‚Äôre too hungry to keep focus. Lots of people in war torn countries, or developing countries, or even just areas hard hit by natural or socioeconomic disaster would have more time and energy to devote to their other needs if they always had enough food to eat.

title: writing prompts
writing_prompt:
writing prompt #871

‚ÄúIn a prepared statement ‚Ä¶‚Äù

If you listen to the news, you hear this phrase quite a bit. You usually hear it when something crazy has happened and someone important needs to respond but doesn‚Äôt want to speak extemporaneously (without preparation) and needs to be careful about how they word their reaction.

In a prepared statement, the writer of the words must shape the message and the words carefully to make sure to say just the right thing. This is your task: to craft a ‚Äúprepared statement‚Äù to respond to a difficult situation.

Prepare the statement for this situation:

The star player in the NBA responds to the decision that basketball hoops will now officially be raised to 20 feet high, twice as high as before.

Narrative option: tell the story of this situation and include the prepared statement in the narrative.

title: writing prompts
writing_prompt:
writing prompt #870

title: writing prompts
writing_prompt:
writing prompt #867

‚ÄúWhat a frightening thing is the human, a mass of gauges and dials and registers, and we can only read a few and those perhaps not accurately.‚Äù ‚ÄîJohn Steinbeck

If you made a control panel for human beings with four sliders or dials that you can adjust to make changes to yourself ‚Äî or those around you ‚Äî what should those four sliders adjust? Strength? Intelligence? Happiness? Adventurousness? Creativity? Humor? Make your choices, explain them, and share your plans for how you will use this human control panel for good or for evil. What if, like the quote from Steinbeck suggests, the control panel is quite inaccurate and frequently malfunctions?

Narrative option: tell the story of an inaccurate human control panel.
response:
An author once put the human condition into words, as authors tend to do. ‚ÄúWhat a frightening thing is the human, a mass of gauges and dials and registers, and we can only read a few and those perhaps not accurately.‚Äù  

Of course, authors are the seers of reality, and once Steinbeck gave his diagnosis, science moved in. I wonder what they felt back then, when the control panel was revealed to the world. 

The history sites only tell us about the wars that were fought. First, those who wanted control vs those who were against altering the natural order. Then, those who wanted autonomy against those who believed settings should be moderated by Oversight.  

We almost didn‚Äôt make it through the autonomy war.  

These days, Oversight intercedes when someone is unable to moderate themselves. They dial down impulses in the criminally minded, dial up empathy in those who are wired to hurt others.   

When I was young, I had a friend who was prone to emotional outbursts. I never knew whether Grey would be happy or sad, angry or elated. I didn‚Äôt care. I loved him because of his struggle, not despite it. My parents warned me not to associate with him, that he would only bring me down with him. All I knew was he was beautiful. That he could paint through his pain. That the world was a better place for his creative visions.  

His neurology was incompatible with the chip we all have implanted with the onset of puberty. I tried to help him the same way I‚Äôd helped myself. He refused to let me alter his controls.  

Oversight took him away, and when they brought him back, he never picked up a paintbrush again. Six months later, we buried him. 

That was when I realized that Oversight is not the protector I had been taught they were. That there is no place for neurodiversity in the plan they have for humanity.  

I think and I feel. I see potential, not the reality. I live in hope, not fear. I see the world through a lens of color and emotion.  

They will never find out who I really am. 

I walk into the Oversight Institute every day. I sit at my desk. I read through case files. I save the artists.

#writing prompt #writing

title: writing prompts

Tales from Diagon Alley Dumpster Diving\xa0

Wizard trash can be dangerous ‚Äî but profitable! Dumpster diving involves people going through the trash bins of stores ‚Äî often grocery stores ‚Äî to salvage discarded items like recently expired food or other items that are still useful, even though they‚Äôve been thrown away. The fictional setting of Diagon Alley has dozens of stores that sell wizarding paraphernalia ‚Äî and you and a few friends are seeing what you can scavenge from the dumpsters behind the alley. writing_prompt:

Welcome to your new bedroom. It‚Äôs a bit strange. It does have four walls, one of which has a door to the hallway and the rest of the house ‚Ä¶ but each of the other three walls has a giant portal ‚Ä¶ to anywhere. At least that‚Äôs what the instructions beside the portal say. There‚Äôs only one catch: you can set the portal to take you anywhere, but you can only set it once. Once you‚Äôve picked where each portal goes, you can‚Äôt switch them. Where do you pick for your three portals? Why? What will you do with them? Explain your portal choices or tell the story of a character discovering the portals.

title: A Writing Prompt a Day
description: Sometimes all we need is a little inspiration. This blog will provide one writing prompt each day. Your job is to turn it into something wonderful.
writing_prompt: Write a piece about a near death experience
response:
'What's that?''

She was pointing to a small blue object, too distant to make out just yet. But they were traveling pretty quickly, and soon enough his eyes adjusted to the shape as they careened by. It passed below them in a near-blur, becoming distant again behind them in a mere blink of the eye.

''It was a car.''

''Oh.''

The girl then pointed to another object. Red this time. Just as before it was too far to really understand what it was just yet, but soon enough they passed over it and the man was able to smile.

''That,'' he clicked his teeth, ''was a boat.''

''Oh.''

There was nothing for a long time, just the inky black and the sense that they were traveling quickly forwards. She'd long since stopped trying to grab at the nothingness with her little hands for purchase. Their forward motion was perpetual, unending, and if I were to be fully honest, at a relatively safe speed. No more than eighty miles per hour, I assure you.

Her hair streamed behind her by the ever-present wind, and she winced once again as a piece whipped around and slapped her across the eyes. It stung and she was tired of reaching up to fix it.

She didn't understand how the man beside her looked completely still even in all of the wind; if she were older and had a better vocabulary, she'd be able to explain why his stillness unnerved her so much after all this time. But she was only five. And such thoughts weren't conducive to the problem at hand. So she kept reminding herself that it wasn't important and to focus on the bigger things.
Namely, the fact that they had been doing this for far too long, and she was far too tired, and she just wanted to go home. Her mother was probably very angry by now. She was sure she had missed more than one dinner by this point.

She wondered if her dad had made it home. He'd been with her, in the beginning. A lot of people had, actually, but one by one they had dissolved until only she and the man remained. When would it be her turn? She's been so very patient and understanding, why couldn't she just go home too?

''How much longer?'' she whined around a yawn. ''I hate this.''

''Not much longer now,'' the man soothed. If he could, he would have pat her head for comfort. He hated dealing with the tiny ones.

Oh, he wasn't scared of children. He dealt with children all the time. It was just... the tiny ones always made him a little sad. His chest always bloomed with a bruise when he had to take a tiny one. 

The same kind of bruise you would feel in your chest if you were to, say, see a puppy be hit by a semi going one-hundred-twelve miles per hour on the freeway. Graphic? Yes. Mentally scarring? Oh, most assuredly. But you'd also be able to take solace in the fact that it was a quick and sort-of painless death, right? I mean, who really feels being hit by a semi at one-hundred-twelve miles per hour? You're liquefied within seconds. Not much pain in that.

''What's that?''

A purple object.

''Ah,'' the man breathed a sigh of relief. ''That's your stop.''

They were still moving forward, but as the purple object drew close it somehow managed to keep pace with them. It was her dad's car. Flying just as quickly as they were, just below them, in all its grapey glory.

She'd never been happier to see her dad's purple car.

She looked over at the man.

''But how do I st--'' As she spoke the man had turned towards her and raised his leg behind him in a funny way. Like one of the footballer's her mom liked to watch on the television.

And then he kicked her before she could even finish her question. Square in the butt. And she went flying towards--

''She's alive! She's alive!''

Olivia opened her eyes. A man was holding her aloft like a trophy. Her dad's purple car was a blurry blob behind him as he walked up a sharp incline and passed her over to more hands. Her head hurt too much to keep her eyes open so she shut them again. Her head lolled towards the side. Her cheeks stung with the movement, still chapped from the hours of wind.

She was placed on something soft but thin. Everything was too loud. Too bright, even with her eyes closed.

She still felt as if she were flying. 
#lets pretend i know how to write on my own without an editor#PRETEND#in a world where an idiot pulls a child out of a car crash when their neck could have easily been broken

title: A Writing Prompt a Day
description: Sometimes all we need is a little inspiration. This blog will provide one writing prompt each day. Your job is to turn it into something wonderful.
writing_prompt: Write a piece about something hiding in the grass
response: The grass? I always avoided it. Never even looked at it, in fear that it would, one day, look back. That one day finally came. I told Pa how scared I was of the tall grass, how it whispered in the wind. In Pa's words, I should "grow up" and "face my fears to help an old lady." Despite my protest, He insisted that I take Ms. Marsh the bag of tattered garments, as she was an old seamstress and could not acquire the clothing on her own accord. Finally giving up, I travel down the gravel road to Ms. Marsh's house. I made sure to take our dog, Lucky. He tended to comfort me in times of stress, and I was stressed. The thing about Ms. Marsh's house is that you had to pass the tall grass to make it there. That's what made the journey difficult. Still, I went. I thought maybe, "It wouldn't be so bad." Boy, was I wrong. Before I knew it, I was in front of the grass. I held Lucky's collar tightly as I walked with my head down. I walked at a fast pace, making sure not to drop the bag of garments in the process. I could hear faint whispering coming from the grass as I walked. My breathing became heavy, but I reminded myself I was almost past the grass. That's when I came to a sudden halt by Lucky. He had stopped and was obviously bothered by something in the grass.  The grass began to rustle as if something were to appear out of it. Before anything had the chance to come out, I picked up Lucky by his torso and ran. He barked until we were finally past the grass. For a moment, when running, I thought the grass had shaken. Approaching Ms. Marsh's house, I was out of breath. Lucky was a big dog weighing about one-sixty. The bag was at least twenty pounds. I weighed about forty pounds less than that. So you can imagine that wasn't easy. I walked up the steps of Ms. Marsh's porch. Her porch was always cluttered with random junk that Pa helped her move from time to time.  I ring the doorbell and wait for Ms. Marsh to come out. Soon after, she walks out and greets me with a small but cheery "Hello, dear." Somewhat still out of breath, I greet her. I show her the bag of garments loosely hanging out the bag and ask her where she would like me to put them. "This table here is fine," she says as she points to the kitchen table behind her. I began to walk inside the house when I look back to see Lucky. He wasn't following me inside. In fact, he didn't even take a step onto the porch. He started acting weird ever since we approached the house. Despite this, I still went inside. Almost immediately, I notice the state of the interior. Cups scattered across countertops, books fallen off shelves, and a strange aroma that I couldn't exactly name. I set the bag on the table and turned to the door. I was stopped by Ms. Marsh asking me if "I had to leave so soon." I told her Pa needed me home, so I had to get going. This was a lie. Pa never said I had to come home at any specific time, but I did not want to walk home in the dark. After telling Ms. Marsh I had to go, I took Lucky and left. Not long after we left, we were back where we began, In front of the grass. A feeling of dread washed over me. I walked faster than before, free from the burden of the bag weighing me down. Suddenly, I heard a low bellow. I look and move towards the grass as if it was calling me. I froze. It was Ms. Marsh. She looked at me with wide eyes and bellowed in the same low tone I heard before. It felt like hours before I was broken from my stare by noise. I hadn't noticed Lucky's rapid barking or the man peering out of his car, screaming at me to get out of the road. I move out of the way, allowing the man to pass. I look back at the grass to find Ms. Marsh gone. What had I seen? Whatever it was, whoever it was, didn't matter. I ran. I ran home and didn't bother looking back. When I finally made it home, I let out a sigh of relief. I didn't tell Pa what happened or what I saw 'cause I knew he wouldn't believe me. I sat on the porch with Lucky, recollecting my thoughts. After all that happened, I could only ask one thing. Where was Ms. Marsh? #thriller #my writing #writing prompt #slay ig #psychological thriller #i like writing #sometimes #when im not procrastinating on projects #i dont really like this #ehhhhhh #I took me 7 hours to write this#because#i#procrastinate#teehee#hope u like it#if u dont#oh well

title: A Writing Prompt a Day
description: Sometimes all we need is a little inspiration. This blog will provide one writing prompt each day. Your job is to turn it into something wonderful.
writing_prompt: Write a piece that contains two or more versions of the same character
response:
Willow unclasped the worn silver. She let the cord slip through her scarred fingers. The cord was as black as her long hair, contrasted by the milky white crescent moon dangling on it everyday. 

‚ÄúIt was mom‚Äôs.‚Äù She said with sentiment. Her wet eyes and sad smile studied the carved stone.

Willow looked in the mirror. She saw her doppelg√§nger‚Äôs hand stretched out toward herself. The necklace was simple, a round crescent moon with markings carved into it.

She she outstretched her arm beneath the other and let the necklace fall. She then studied it closely. She could see the imperfections now, little chips and dirt built up over the years. Beneath it there was a marbling effect, by a trick of the light it almost glowed.

Willow looked back into the reversed glass. She saw herself once again, but different. The hair on her head was white and cut short, framing her face.

‚ÄúWhat do I do with this?‚Äù She asked, met only with silence.

With no answer, Willow put the cord around her neck and clasped the silver pieces together. The cold stone fell and hung against her skin. Willow stared into the mirror.

Who was she talking to? #writing prompts #writing ideas #writing help #ocs #oc #willow #instability #unstable gift

title: A Writing Prompt a Day
description: Sometimes all we need is a little inspiration. This blog will provide one writing prompt each day. Your job is to turn it into something wonderful.
writing_prompt: Write a piece about an invasive species
response:
The first few sprays of poppies didn't draw any attention; it was the season for flowers to sprout, and seeds could travel easily in woodsy areas. Sure, they weren't exactly native to Hue's small town, but they were sure pretty to look at as you rode by on a bicycle. Kids could be seen picking them the first few days, making tiny, tight-fisted bouquets for their parents or friends. Hue even sat with his little sister Mary and taught her how to make a crown from them by poking a hole in the stem with his nail and pulling another stem through.

It didn't alarm anyone as the flowers spread. Flowers do that. They hopped from one fence to the other, one yard to the next--you could even track their growth by putting your fingers up to your eye. In only a few hours time they'd travel a finger-width, by the next day they'd be four fingers past. And so on and so forth. 

Not everyone liked them; Mrs. Talbot, for example, complained about them every day as Hue walked Mary to school. She'd pull them from her vegetable patch and hold them aloft like she'd finally gotten vengeance and held the head of her worst enemy.  Mr. Lonnie and Mr. Giles, on the other hand, made tea from them they claimed was good for blood circulation and chronic pain. It looked red and smelled terrible.

It took a couple of months for the poppies to cover every inch of grass, choking the life from anything smaller than a sapling. They took over abandoned toys and started to climb fences just around the same time the town called a meeting to address the situation. Regular weed-killers just weren't cutting it and poor Mrs. Talbot had long ago given up the fight--she couldn't pull them out fast enough before more grew to take their place.

Walking Mary to school across concrete sidewalks became piggy-back rides through the growing froth of green and red. The idyllic wonder of a seven year-old was the only thing keeping Hue from the panic that was starting to consume everyone else. 

Some people left, packing up their things and leaving their doors wide open as they drove off into the unknown. But it wasn't just their town. It was the entire county. And it only seemed to be getting worse; the local news kept track with their own special radar. Every day Hue watched the red shape grow wider and wider as it swallowed them up whole.

They had completely taken over by the fifth month. Poppies, a sea of red, black, green, and yellow. Townies had to use machetes to get from one door to the next. Paths were cut daily from house to house, store to store, just so people could get through and live their lives pretending everything was normal. That harmless, thoughtless flowers hadn't taken over and everyone was alright.

The local crops had dried-up. The country was focusing on stopping the spread, not helping the people already affected, and food was scarce as they built a wall to keep the poppies--and the people--in. There were no evacuation efforts. They'd all been left to slowly starve to death.

What wildlife was left had been hunted and eaten. Not even the herbivores could be kept alive subsisting off of only poppies. Fighting was normal, now. Neighbors were no longer helping each other reach their mailbox in the tough tangling vines.

Hue packed up what little they had and took Mary into the last of the trees that used to make up an endless forest. It was eerie, how little noise there was now. No bird calls. No skittering squirrels. Just... quiet.

''What happens when there's no one left?'' Mary asked one night as they stared up at the stars. The trees were gone, left behind somewhere in the miles they'd walked. There was nothing out here except the poppies. At least they made a soft bed.

Hue traced a faint line in the air, connecting one star to another like a connect-the-dots drawing. His stomach growled, low and hungry, but their reserves had long-since dried up. He knew he would have to resort to desperate measures soon.

''I don't know.''

Mary's face, so thin and gaunt now, didn't look right in the darkness. The moon's light bounced off her skin in a way that made her look as if she were glowing from the inside.

''I'm hungry,'' she whispered.

''I know.''

#read this in country bumpkin accent #i am not a profegional i just wanted to have fun

title: A Writing Prompt a Day
description: Sometimes all we need is a little inspiration. This blog will provide one writing prompt each day. Your job is to turn it into something wonderful.
writing_prompt: Write a piece about someone who fails a test or assignment they thought they did well on
response:
A C-minus. A C-fucking-minus.



‚ÄúYou did well,‚Äù their mother said quietly.



Tears pricked at their eyes. ‚ÄúYou worked so hard to teach me those formulas and it‚Äôs‚Äî‚Äù They broke off into an unintelligeble growl. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm going to get an A next time,‚Äù they whispered. ‚ÄúAn A-plus.‚Äù



‚ÄúYou can make mistakes,‚Äù their mother reminded, carding a hand through their hair. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs only human.‚Äù



They choked out a bitter laugh. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre a god, and I was supposed to be your puppet. Neither of us are human.‚Äù



Ei sighed. ‚ÄúThat doesn‚Äôt mean mistakes aren‚Äôt allowed, child. And you know I‚Äôve long since discarded the idea of a puppet. It‚Äôs immoral.‚Äù



‚ÄúSays you,‚Äù they muttered under their breath.



‚ÄúMicah Makoto,‚Äù Ei reprimanded.



‚ÄúWhy did you even give me her name?‚Äù they asked, looking at the letter written in red. ‚ÄúWe both know I‚Äôll never live up to her.‚Äù

hashtags: ['anon ask', 'ask', 'creativepromptsforwriting', 'creativepromptsforwritingask', 'rockstar au', 'rockstar prompts', 'musician prompts', 'band prompts', 'band au', 'prompt list', 'writing prompts']
writing_prompt:
asking_name': 'Anonymous', 'asking_url': None, 'question': '

heyy i saw that in your AU ideas list you have Rockstar AU but no prompts for that, so i was wondering if you could come up with some? especially for a rockstar dating an ‚Äòordinary‚Äô person, not involved in their world. thank you!

', 'answer': '

Hi :)

You’re right, there are no actual Rockstar AU prompts yet.

I found an ask I answered two years ago about a Rockstar dating someone working 9-5, so definitely check my answer for that out!

Rockstar AUs

  1. Dating a rockstar had its perks, but also some downsides. Not being able to go on tour with them, meant missing them for months on end.
  2. They never thought their shift in the hospital would turn out like this. With an international rockstar with a broken arm in front of them because they tried to stage dive and failed.
  3. Social media has a field day when pictures turn up that show the famous rockstar with an unknown person, definitely being on a date.
  4. Their co-workers don’t know that they are dating this rockstar everyone knows. That changes when their rockstar partner comes to work to take them out for dinner.
  5. Going to all their concerts is not possible when working a 9-5 job, but they always try to wait for their partner to come home to say good night.
  6. They’ve started dating when it was still a garage band, playing at proms and bar mitzvahs. They’re still dating but one of them becoming a famous rockstar has turned their life upside down.
  7. Being on tour is not the easiest when their partner can’t come with them. Concerts every other day, city after city, different countries, different time zones. It takes a lot of work to keep a healthy relationship going across the globe.
  8. The band’s partners all have nothing to do with the entertainment business, so they created their own little support group to handle their rockstars together.

More: Band Prompts

I hope you enjoy these and I will link them to the AU list, if I don’t forget again :D

- Jana

You’re right, there are no actual Rockstar AU prompts yet.

I found an ask I answered two years ago about a Rockstar dating someone working 9-5, so definitely check my answer for that out!

Rockstar AUs

  1. Dating a rockstar had its perks, but also some downsides. Not being able to go on tour with them, meant missing them for months on end.
  2. They never thought their shift in the hospital would turn out like this. With an international rockstar with a broken arm in front of them because they tried to stage dive and failed.
  3. Social media has a field day when pictures turn up that show the famous rockstar with an unknown person, definitely being on a date.
  4. Their co-workers don’t know that they are dating this rockstar everyone knows. That changes when their rockstar partner comes to work to take them out for dinner.
  5. Going to all their concerts is not possible when working a 9-5 job, but they always try to wait for their partner to come home to say good night.
  6. They’ve started dating when it was still a garage band, playing at proms and bar mitzvahs. They’re still dating but one of them becoming a famous rockstar has turned their life upside down.
  7. Being on tour is not the easiest when their partner can’t come with them. Concerts every other day, city after city, different countries, different time zones. It takes a lot of work to keep a healthy relationship going across the globe.
  8. The band’s partners all have nothing to do with the entertainment business, so they created their own little support group to handle their rockstars together.

More: Band Prompts

I hope you enjoy these and I will link them to the AU list, if I don’t forget again :D

- Jana
